question: Question_04_(c)
statement:
The following discrete dynamical system describes the yearly migration
of wild horse populations among three areas R, G, and B. Let
\emph{r(t)}, \emph{g(t)}, and \emph{b(t)} be the sizes of the horse
population in areas R, G, and B respectively at the
\emph{t\textsuperscript{th}} year.

\begin{align*}
x(t+1) &= \begin{bmatrix} r(t+1) \\ g(t+1) \\ b(t+1) \end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/3 \\
r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/2 \\
g(t)/3 + b(t)/6
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/3 \\ 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/2 \\ 0 & 1/3 & 1/6 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} r(t) \\ g(t) \\ b(t) \end{bmatrix} \\
&= Ax(t)\end{align*}

Where the Markov matrix \emph{A} describes how the horses move among
these areas from one year to the next. The 1st column indicates that
each year 1/2 of the horses in area R remain in area R and 1/2 will
migrate to area G. The 2nd column shows that horses in area G will be
evenly distributed in the three areas one year later. The 3rd column
implies that, of the horses in area B, 1/3 will migrate to area R, 1/2
will migrate to area G, and only 1/6 will remain in area B.

We assume that no horses are lost and no new horses are added and that
initially (i.e. at \emph{t = 0}), there are a total of 350 horses all
located in area B. Thus $\vec x(0) = [0\ 0\ 350]^T$.

\textbf{(c)} Find a matrix \emph{S} so that
$S^{-1}AS = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & \lambda_3 \end{bmatrix}$
where \emph{λ\textsubscript{1}}, \emph{λ\textsubscript{2}},
\emph{λ\textsubscript{3}} are the eigenvalues found in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/April_2006/Question_04_(a)}{part
(a)}.
sols:
$AS = \Lambda S$ where $\Lambda$ is the matrix with the eigenvalues on
the diagonal and S is a matrix with eigenvectors as the columns. In this
case S will be invertible so we can modify the equation to
$S^{-1}AS = \Lambda$

So the matrix S is a 3x3 matrix with columns that equal the
eigenvectors. Using the same method to find the eigenvectors as in part
(b) we get the following eigenvectors

$\lambda_{1} = 1$ has eigenvector
$v = \left[ \begin{array}{c} \frac{2}{5} \\ \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{6}{35} \end{array} \right]$

$\lambda_{2} = \frac{1}{6}$ has eigenvector
$v = \left[ \begin{array}{c} -\frac{1}{2} \\ 0 \\ \frac{1}{2} \end{array} \right]$

$\lambda_{3} = -\frac{1}{6}$ has eigenvector
$v = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 0 \\ -\frac{1}{2} \\ \frac{1}{2} \end{array} \right]$

Therefore we have the matrix S
$S = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} \frac{2}{5} & -\frac{1}{2} & 0 \\ \frac{3}{7} & 0 & -\frac{1}{2} \\ \frac{6}{35} & \frac{1}{2} & \frac{1}{2} \end{array} \right]$
